text.p: The Turkish treasury sharply increased the sale amount in its second inflation indexed, two-year bond auction, further fuelling cash demand on Tuesday, bankers said.
They said liquidity demand was already firm due to continuing income tax payments, bankers said.

The Treasury sold 109.8 trillion lira of the bonds at a risk premium of 24 percent, compared to 18.6 trillion lira sale and 25 percent risk premium at the first inflation-indexed bond sale on March 4.
Bankers said the sale amount was above the market's previous expectations and the central bank began funding the banks immediately after the results were announced.
Banks will pay 108.7 trillion lira for the auction on Wednesday when they will collect 68.1 trillion lira from the central bank for maturing reverse repos.
It lent 3.6 trillion lira at 72 percent overnight, 21.8 trillion lira at 67 percent on tmrw/next and 16 trillion lira at 68 percent via tmrw/week.

The average overnight money rate eased to 70.23 percent from Monday's 71.79 percent because the rates dipped to a low of 60 percent earlier in the day due to funding by the central bank and a state bank on the overnight repo market, bankers said.
The average overnight repo rate leapt to 74.28 percent from Monday's 71.82.
Bond yields eased by around a percentage point due to demand in outstanding papers before and after the auction.
Turkish lira slightly firmed to 127,630 against the dollar from Monday's 127,650 close as the dollar eased versus the mark.
